messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 47 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Non-Clashing Teaching Maps for Balls in GraphsThis work was supported by the Austrian Science Foundation (FWF, project Y1329) and the ANR projects DISTANCIA (ANR-17-CE40-0015) and DUCAT (ANR-20-CE48-0006).

Paper Abstract: Abstract Recently, non-clashing teaching was introduced by Kirkpatrick et al. [ALT 2019] and Fallat et al. [JMLR 2023], and it was shown to be the most efficient machine teaching model that satisfies the benchmark for collusion-avoidance set by Goldman and Mathias. A teaching map T𝑇T for a concept class 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C} assigns a (teaching) set T​(C)𝑇𝐶T(C) of examples to each concept C∈𝒞𝐶𝒞C\in\mathcal{C}. A teaching map is non-clashing if no pair of concepts of 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C} are consistent with the union of their teaching sets. The size of a non-clashing teaching map (NCTM) T𝑇T is the maximum size of a teaching set T​(C)𝑇𝐶T(C), C∈𝒞𝐶𝒞C\in\mathcal{C}. The non-clashing teaching dimension NCTD⁡(𝒞)NCTD𝒞\operatorname{NCTD}(\mathcal{C}) of 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C} is the minimum size of an NCTM for 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C}. NCTM+s and NCTD(𝒞)+{}^{+}(\mathcal{C}) are defined analogously, except that the teacher may only use positive examples. We investigate NCTMs and NCTM+s for the concept class ℬ​(G)ℬ𝐺\mathcal{B}(G) consisting of all balls of a graph G𝐺G. We show that the associated decision problem B-NCTD+ for NCTD+ is \NP-complete in split, co-bipartite, and bipartite graphs. Surprisingly, we even prove that, unless the ETH fails, B-NCTD+ does not admit an algorithm running in time 22o​(𝚟𝚌)⋅n𝒪​(1)⋅superscript2superscript2𝑜𝚟𝚌superscript𝑛𝒪12^{2^{o(\mathtt{vc})}}\cdot n^{\mathcal{O}(1)}, nor a kernelization algorithm outputting a kernel with 2o​(𝚟𝚌)superscript2𝑜𝚟𝚌2^{o(\mathtt{vc})} vertices, where 𝚟𝚌𝚟𝚌\mathtt{vc} is the vertex cover number of G𝐺G. These are two extremely rare results: it is only the second (fourth, respectively) problem in \NP to admit such a double-exponential lower bound parameterized by 𝚟𝚌𝚟𝚌\mathtt{vc} (the treewidth, respectively), and only one of very few problems to admit such an ETH-based conditional lower bound on the number of vertices in a kernel. We complement these lower bounds with matching upper bounds. For trees, interval graphs, cycles, and trees of cycles, we then derive NCTM+s or NCTMs for ℬ​(G)ℬ𝐺\mathcal{B}(G) of size proportional to the VC-dimension of ℬ​(G)ℬ𝐺\mathcal{B}(G). Finally, for Gromov-hyperbolic graphs, we design an approximate version of an NCTM+ for ℬ​(G)ℬ𝐺\mathcal{B}(G) of small size, in which only pairs of balls that have Hausdorff distance larger than some constant must satisfy the non-clashing condition.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 47 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 47"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Trajectories and keyframes for kinesthetic teaching: A human-robot interaction perspective",
        "Combinatorics of Finite Sets",
        "Finding patterns common to a set of strings",
        "Inductive inference of formal languages from positive data",
        "Measuring teachability using variants of the teaching dimension",
        "On the distance identifying set meta-problem and applications to the complexity of identifying problems on graphs",
        "Oriented Matroids, volume 46 of Encyclopedia of Mathematics and its Applications",
        "VC-dimension and Erdős–Pósa property",
        "Machine teaching for inverse reinforcement learning: Algorithms and applications",
        "Sample compression schemes for balls in graphs",
        "Unlabeled sample compression schemes and corner peelings for ample and maximum classes",
        "On the parameterized complexity of biclique cover and partition",
        "Understanding the role of adaptivity in machine teaching: The case of version space learners",
        "On covering planar graphs with a fixed number of balls",
        "Labeled sample compression schemes for complexes of oriented matroids",
        "Parameterized Algorithms",
        "Known algorithms for edge clique cover are probably optimal",
        "Learning regular languages from simple positive examples",
        "Diameter computation on H𝐻H-minor free graphs and graphs of bounded (distance) VC-dimension",
        "On batch teaching without collusion",
        "Sample compression, learnability, and the Vapnik-Chervonenkis dimension",
        "Tight (double) exponential bounds for NP-complete problems: Treewidth and vertex cover parameterizations",
        "Preference-based teaching",
        "On the complexity of teaching",
        "Teaching a smarter learner",
        "Hyperbolic groups",
        "Showing versus doing: Teaching by demonstration",
        "Which problems have strongly exponential complexity?",
        "Optimal collusion-free teaching",
        "Unlabelled compression schemes for maximum classes",
        "Parameterized max min feedback vertex set",
        "Relating data compression and learnability",
        "Preference-based batch and sequential teaching: Towards a unified view of models",
        "Using machine teaching to identify optimal training-set attacks on machine learners",
        "Labeled compression schemes for extremal classes",
        "Unlabeled compression schemes exceeding the VC-dimension",
        "Learning to recommend from positive evidence",
        "Teachability in computational learning",
        "Tournaments, johnson graphs, and NC-teaching",
        "Inducing probabilistic grammars by Bayesian model merging",
        "Learning about objects with human teachers",
        "PSoL: a positive sample only learning algorithm for finding non-coding RNA genes",
        "Learning from positive examples when the negative class is undetermined - microRNA gene identification",
        "Training set debugging using trusted items",
        "Machine teaching: An inverse problem to machine learning and an approach toward optimal education",
        "An overview of machine teaching",
        "Models of cooperative teaching and learning"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 47 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Non-Clashing Teaching Maps for Balls in GraphsThis work was supported by the Austrian Science Foundation (FWF, project Y1329) and the ANR projects DISTANCIA (ANR-17-CE40-0015) and DUCAT (ANR-20-CE48-0006)., providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
